title: Friday, 12th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM

Hi there

PM

Thought I'd give you a visual snapshot showing why we are taking next week off

PM

(No, not a sun kissed beach; I'm off to Scotland...)

11:03 am
PM

PM

That's the muppet tab on Investegate

PM

There's precious little news

11:03 am
PM

There's so little, statements from unlisted companies are in the "most popular" list

BE

No rightards either, by the looks of things.

BE

We're on our own.

PM

Hmm

PM

Say something, somebody

PM

Hey!

11:04 am

Morning

Sunny Friday in early August. One has to expect numbers to be down.

Just so we not completely spewing pixels into the ether

11:05 am
PM

We'll only be off for a week

PM

I have to go to Thurso, which is so far north there's only cold sea beyond it

PM

My wife, Kate, was born there. And has never been back

11:06 am
BE

(@BBOC: then I retract it. We sometimes used the term around 2010, when things could be a bit more firey between the panels.)

BE

Thurso's nice. Ish.

PM

There's a rare thing -- a Bryce Elder retraction!

11:07 am
PM

Screenshot it, quick

BE

I'm perfectly willing to change my opinion on stuff that doesn't matter a fig, such as slinging insults at the readers. Important stuff, less so.

BE

(See the past two sessions for more. We won't recap.)

11:08 am
BE

So where do we begin?

undefined
PM

Hey, the Footsie's up 0.08% now

11:08 am
PM

Guess we go straight to Restaurant group

BE

I guess we do. CEO punted.

PM

Poor Danny Breithaupt

11:09 am
PM

Stock up 13.5% on his departure

BE

Guy who ran Betfair comes in. Because you want a bookmaker in charge of your lunch.

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 423.50, up 46.7 (+12.39%), High: 423.50, Low: 389.60, Volume: 3.93m
11:09 am
PM

PM

Andy McCue

BE

Sorry, not Betfair. Paddy Power. I mentally merged them. What's the upside here? Well ..........

11:11 am
BE

Debbie Hewitt, the chairman, says Andy "brings strong consumer, people and brand-led CEO credentials, with very relevant experience from a multi-site business. His extensive strategic background, coupled with a strong commercial flair, proven hands-on operational expertise and digital credentials, will bring considerable strength and new skills to the leadership of our Executive Team."

BE

(@cheeckychappy: never heard of it. Not my side of the country.)

BE

What does any of that mean? Not much.

11:12 am
BE

Interested to see how "digital credentials" will help Frankie & Benny's though.

PM

They need to close a few Frankie & Benny's

PM

There's just too many

11:12 am
BE

Well, if I may ............

BE

Restaurant Group's problems are quite interesting in the scheme of things.

BE

It was a captive-customer business.

11:13 am
BE

People ate there because they didn't have a choice. I've been to a Frankie & Benny's and I can assure you it was not by choice.

BE

But retail spending dropped a bit, which led malls and stuff to shift more space towards food

BE

That left Restaurant Group with the option of letting competitors in, which would remove the captive-customer benefit ....

11:15 am
BE

... or bid themselves for the same sites, cannibalising its own business with other brands.

BE

The weakest, stalest brand in the portfolio is Frankie & Benny's. New York Italian has a pretty old fashioned and limited appeal.

BE

So it's not just that Frankie & Benny's is rubbish (which it is, undeniably). It's also that, as the weakest of the pack, Restaurant Group has been forced to cannibalise it to survive.

11:17 am
PM

Very interesting Bryce

BE

What can Mr McCue do about this? No idea. None whatsoever.

PM

Coming from the gaming world, he'll be big into data i guess

11:17 am
BE

Retail space is getting converted to food at a hell of a rate and Restaurant Group just doesn't have the capex available to protect its market.

BE

Against that is a flood of PE money to back anyone with a rollout concept that has "street food" or "fusion" or "casual" in its business pitch.

PM

Retail space is getting converted to crap food

11:19 am
PM

All these roll-outs are appalling

PM

I failed to take your advice the other night on suitable eatery. Ended up at a cheapo Ramsey place. Awful. And not particularly cheap either

BE

Yeah, well, that's you failing to take my advice.

11:20 am
PM

INdeed

BE

And Ramsay does what he does. It's not quite the same market.

PM

Sure

11:21 am
BE

Also, there are some decent-ish low-end chain operators -- Cote isn't awful, for instance. And anyone remembering the glory days London being full of single joints doing top-class food for not too much is misremembering quite dramatically.

BE

But returning to the point ..............

BE

What can McCue do? Canaccord doesn't know, but they're prepared to bet on him succeeding at whatever he does do.

11:22 am
BE

We are upgrading our recommendation on Restaurant Group to BUY from Hold and
boosting our share price target to 550p (was 276p), implying 49% potential upside,
following the replacement of CEO Danny Breithaupt with Andy McCue, ex CEO of Paddy
Power, and ahead of the interims and publication of its strategic review on 26th August.
Our target price is based on a sum-of-the-parts methodology as Restaurant Group
comprises several discrete businesses and brands with the issues centred on the major
brand, Frankie & Benny’s. We believe that the business is fixable. Chairman Debbie
Hewitt has bought time with the defenestration of the FD and now the CEO, but we
believe that private equity players will still be watching very carefully from the sidelines.

BE

The problems Restaurant Group faces are not unique. Maturing brands inevitably
require constant innovation and occasional reinvention and there are many positive
case studies in the market that suggest it can be done. We highlight a checklist of
actions that investors should expect to read in the review: exit poorly performing sites,
continue to develop the brand portfolio, reposition Frankie & Benny's, reduce and re-
direct capex, improve digital marketing capability, reduce the overheads, review returns
to shareholders including share buybacks.
New CEO Andy McCue was CEO of Paddy Power where he embedded a new growth
strategy which delivered record revenues and profits, as well as playing a main role in the
merger with Betfair. New CFO Barry Nightingale was CFO of Monarch Airlines and played
a 'key role' in returning it to profitability. The executive team has also been strengthened
by the appointment of Spencer Ayers as new managing director for Frankie & Benny’s.
He worked for Restaurant Group as operations director from January 2004 to April 2010
but left to pursue a career in the Middle East working for the Alshaya Group responsible
for Le Pain Quotidien and Pizza Express.
Potential private equity and trade buyers will likely not lose interest until the share price
has recovered. A trade buyer would have the advantage of having the management
and brands to help restructure the portfolio and it would also be able to capture the
synergies of putting two businesses together. In our view - and as has been speculated
in the press - the two strongest candidates for a potential take-over would be the Casual
Dining Group (Café Rouge, Bella Italia) owned by Apollo Global Management and
Gondola (Pizza Express and ASK Pizza) owned by China’s Honey Capital.

BE

Accepting our reasonable assumptions for other parts of the business and a negative
value of £10m for the tail restaurants, then the core Frankie & Benny’s business is
valued at just 3.0x EBITDA or just £0.9m/site at the current share price. We think this is
too low and our 550p share price target assumes a valuation of 8.0x EBITDA, or £2.4m
per site based on our FY16 forecasts. A recovery of trading to historic levels for Frankie
& Benny’s would increase its unit EBITDA towards £350k/site in our view and should
warrant a higher valuation multiple and could drive a valuation approaching 680p.

11:23 am
BE

The PE line's gone quiet, incidentally.

BE

In that it's a business at 6 times EBITDA without any asset backing, it looked a bit risky as an idea.

BE

Particularly into a saturated market, with PE having a good understanding of the saturation having been wholly responsible for it.

11:24 am
BE

Barclays too.

BE

We believe that the announcement that the company has appointed Andy McCue as CEO will be taken positively. He will replace Danny Breithaupt, who will leave the company with immediate effect. McCue will join the company on September 19th, so in the meantime Chairman Debbie Hewitt “will take a more active role in the business” to ensure “momentum on the operating strategy review” remains. We believe that the positive share price reaction is entirely understandable, and investor interest will be high in this appointment, given Andy McCue has a strong reputation (among other things) for developing PaddyPower’s UK retail business into a highly profitable estate. The table below illustrates the progression of PaddyPower’s UK Retail EBIT under his tenure (appointment as Managing Director, UK Retail in 2009 after joining in 2006 as Head of Strategy). Although the success of the UK operations cannot all be down to one individual, it is clearly an impressive performance and one that cannot be ignored in the context of The Restaurant Group.

BE

What could the strategy review look like? Lower prices, improved quality, and a potential estate rationalisation

We have written in detail about the company’s potential strategic options in the following report: "Strategy review: What's on the menu?" 20th June 2016. In this report, we illustrated that every 100bps off group gross margins could cut EPS by c9% vs FY16E, and every 1% off LFL sales would lower EPS by c5%.

This analysis was applied to the entire estate, which is potentially harsh given that the real problem areas appear to be within a subset of sites at the core Frankie & Benny’s brand (Frankie and Benny’s is c52% of the estate). We currently assume 23 new sites in FY17 (vs 30 in FY16), but we believe a more drastic cut to the rollout could be desirable if ROCE is falling. This would allow the company to focus on problem areas, preserve cash, and benefit when poorly capitalised competitors suffer from the industry headwinds of oversupply, rising rents, and National Living Wage cost increases.

Our Equal Weight rating balances the significant EPS headwinds that could stem from a rollout cut, a gross margin rebasing, and the severe industry headwinds vs. the turnaround potential of what was once a ‘sector darling’, some excellent operations (especially Pub Restaurants, and the Concessions business) and the more reasonable valuation with the shares -40% year-to-date. We believe that the credibility of a potential turnaround has increased with a new CEO who has a strong reputation, albeit the industry challenges mean that this take place with an extremely challenging backdrop.

Valuation at 411p, after this morning’s c9% spike, on FY17 (where we assume a modest fall in PBT to £72m vs £74m in FY16): Valuation (FY17): P/E 14.8x, EV/EBITDA 7.3x, FCF yield 8%, divi yield 3.4%.

11:33 am
BE

(@Boncoeur: the Blanc business is run by a former boss of TFI Friday, incidentally.)

BE

Yes, this is all about alleged uncompetitive practices in sexed semen.

BE

Seriously. I'm just quoting here.

11:34 am
BE

Have a downgrade from N+1 Singer, so I don't have to type any more.

BE

The first jury verdicts in the long-running two-way litigation between Genus’ ABS (bovine) and US-based Sexing Technologies (‘ST’), announced this week, have in our view been disappointing for Genus. It has been announced this morning that the Wisconsin jury concluded that two of ST’s patents were infringed by ABS, and that Genus had breached confidentiality agreements. This follows the verdict announced yesterday that although ST had engaged in anti-competitive practises in relation to sexed semen, Genus had not been able to prove that it suffered a loss as a result. We believe that damages are likely to be awarded against Genus. We move our cautious Hold recommendation to Sell, noting the strong share price performance in the run-up to today’s verdict.

BE

And VSA.

11:34 am
BE

This important trial for GNS began on 1 August and was expected to last up to three weeks. It concerns GNS’ sexed semen operations, which typically make up 5-10% of GNS’ total straw sales.

Following a mixed result in its first update yesterday (Sexing Technologies had maintained a monopoly since July 2012 but GNS had not suffered injury as a result of it), this second set of rulings is clearly not in favour of the company.

The best case scenario from this court case would have resulted in financial compensation (c£6m spent on legal costs since 2014) as well as the immediate go-ahead to launch its own in-house developed sexed semen technology (ramp-up in FY 2017, full impact FY 2018), saving GNS c£5m per year in operating costs (c1.5% of group operating costs).

It seems likely that GNS may now be ordered to pay damages. We had assumed that GNS would be allowed to continue to use the licensed technology from Sexing Technologies until its current contract expires in 2017. However, we are now waiting to see what the implications for its existing contract with Sexing Technologies, given GNS has been ruled to have breached confidentiality obligations, and also whether GNS will be free to launch its own sexed semen technology.

As we have previously said, whatever the result of this action, it is likely that there will be an appeal either way.

The GNS share price has had a significant post-Brexit run-up, increasing more than 30%, from a level that we already believed overvalued the company. We would continue to take the opportunity to take profits at the current level.

BE

If you want to read more about semen sorting technologies, the patents are #8,206,987 and #8,198,092.

On 9 August, Mr Roper took up 1,206,816 Nil Paid Rights and on 11 August, Mr Roper took up 7,515,011 Nil Paid Rights, being the remainder of his entitlement, each at a price per Nil Paid Right of 95 pence and an aggregate cost of £8,285,735.65;

11:41 am
BE

Hm. There's something about the whole Melrose-Nortek story that contradicts what I force myself to believe about efficient markets. Either Melrose is silly overvalued now or Nortek was silly undervalued then. I see no alternative readings.

undefined
BE

In terms of sellside, there's not much.

11:42 am
BE

Ladbrokes getting a push from Citi.

Ladbrokes PLC (LAD:LSE): Last: 158.10, up 4.7 (+3.06%), High: 159.70, Low: 153.70, Volume: 4.29m
BE

 Upgrade to Buy. The CMA recently approved the Ladbrokes/Coral merger, subject
to 350-400 shop disposals, and we now include Coral in our formal forecasts. We
expect EPS to increase from 6.6p for Ladbrokes stand alone in FY16E to 16.8p in
FY19E driven by announced synergies and shared best practice. Strong cash
generation should support a c5% dividend yield and rapid debt pay down. Our
SOTP target for the combined group is 180p (from 125p) and we upgrade to Buy.

11:43 am
BE

 Post synergy margins indicate further upside. We factor in £65m of announced
cost synergies by FY19 and assume that around £25m of lost EBITDA from c400
shop disposals can be recouped. In particular we assume an alignment of trading
strategies drives a c1pp improvement in Ladbrokes GW margins. By FY19 we
expect post synergy retail margins of 17.9% and online margins of 15.5%. Best in
class online margins are over 20% suggesting upside potential. We assume
Ladbrokes online EBIT margins remain half of those at Coral despite similar net
revenues. Closing this gap could add over 10% to FY19E EPS

BE

 Momentum at both is good. We see encouraging trends at both businesses.
Coral’s online business looks to be on track to have tripled EBITDA over the last 3
years. Last week Ladbrokes delivered good H1 results which seemed to mark a
step change after years of disappointment. Although much of the EBIT beat was
driven by sports results, underlying momentum was strong with underlying online
sports stakes +30%, actives +39% and gaming net revenue +27%. However
marketing costs and free bets are elevated and investors will be need to see
evidence that this growth can be converted profitably going forward.

BE

 Strong cash generation. Post integration we expect 2/3 of combined EBIT will
come from retail, with associated strong cash generation. FY17 will likely be
focused on integration but by FY18E we expect FCF of over £250m (9.5% yield).
This should support a c5% dividend yield and allow good debt pay down with
ND/EBITDA at around 1.5x by end FY18E.

11:44 am
BE

Nothing fresh on William Hill, by the way. Though all three sets of managements have been out on hearts-and-minds tours this week, so expect plenty of weekend press coverage.

Which is one of Bloomberg's auto-generated story thingmybobs, which are of ..... I'll be polite here .... limited value.

Leaving us all to scramble around trying to find reasons to a move that, in the scheme of things, would normally have been ignored.

11:53 am

11:54 am

Following Merlin’s H116 results, we are cutting our EBITDA EPS
estimates by -3.2% -1.7% for FY16e and by -4.4% -2.5% for FY17e-
FY20e. This predominantly reflects weaker trading in the Midway
division, where we now model -0.5% like-for-like growth and 37.5%
EBITDA margins for FY16e (previously +2.0% 39.2%), partly offset by
a lower group tax rate (JPMe 26%, previously 28%). Our August-2017
DCF PT moves to 450p accordingly (was 464p to July-2017).

BE
